body:
### Describe the bug

With Cython 3.1.3, when compiling for the limited API (`-DPy_LIMITED_API=0x030A0000`), the function `__Pyx_PyUnicode_AsStringAndSize` produces a compiler warning with g++-11:
```
wrap.cpp:433:55: error: 'unicode_length' may be used uninitialized [-Werror=maybe-uninitialized]
  433 |   #define CYTHON_MAYBE_UNUSED_VAR(x) CYTHON_UNUSED_VAR(x)
      |                                      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^~~
wrap.cpp:12041:9: note: in expansion of macro 'CYTHON_MAYBE_UNUSED_VAR'
12041 |         CYTHON_MAYBE_UNUSED_VAR(unicode_length); // only for __PYX_DEFAULT_STRING_ENCODING_IS_ASCII
      |         ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
wrap.cpp:427:29: note: by argument 1 of type 'const long int&' to 'void CYTHON_UNUSED_VAR(const T&) [with T = long int]' declared here
  427 |      template<class T> void CYTHON_UNUSED_VAR( const T& ) { }
      |                             ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
wrap.cpp:12040:20: note: 'unicode_length' declared here
12040 |         Py_ssize_t unicode_length;
      |                    ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~
cc1plus: all warnings being treated as errors
```
Line 12035 is the start of `__Pyx_PyUnicode_AsStringAndSize`.

I'm not sure why `CYTHON_UNUSED_VAR` is using a weird definition in C++ mode that makes the compiler believe the value is actually used.
Workaround: compile with `-DCYTHON_UNUSED_VAR(x)=(void)(x)` (equivalent to what Cython always uses for C).

### Code to reproduce the behaviour:

Not sure which part of my code pulled in this function, probably related to a Python object -> `std::string` conversion.

### Expected behaviour

_No response_

### OS

Linux

### Python version

3.10.0

### Cython version

3.1.3

### Additional context

_No response_
title: [BUG] maybe-uninitialized compiler warning in __Pyx_PyUnicode_AsStringAndSize
